Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Designing Glass Structures for Femtosecond Laser Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Ultrafast lasers with pulses shorter than a trillionth of a second can be used to create micron-sized structures inside a piece of glass. This fabrication method provides a platform for the fabrication of photonic devices and circuits with applications in optical communications, bio-imaging and -sensing and nanotechnology. In order to exploit the full potential of this ultrafast laser 'writing' technique it is important to design materials that are optimized both in terms of device properties and laser processing behavior. Towards this goal this project aims to develop such materials as well as a detailed understanding of how the laser changes the materials structure on a microscopic scale. The research is a collaboration between UC Davis and Missouri S&T and provides training for graduate, undergraduate and pre-college students in state-of-the-art materials science and optical techniques, research opportunities for undergraduates and outreach activities at the pre-college level.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Femtosecond (fs)-laser writing of optical waveguides inside glass substrates is a promising technique for fabricating integrated photonic devices. The quality of the device is determined by the response of the glass to fs laser processing conditions as well as glass composition. Phosphate glasses, which are of interest as host materials for active devices since they allow incorporation of high concentrations of rare earth ions, typically produce negative refractive index changes in the laser-exposed regions, leading to poor optical performance. However, certain compositions exhibit positive refractive index changes that are desirable for device fabrication. The overall objective of the project is to develop a fundamental understanding of the materials parameters that govern the response of phosphate glass to femtosecond laser irradiation. Experiments are conducted to determine the relationships between glass structure and response to fs-laser processing and to characterize fs-laser induced changes in glass structure using fluorescence, Raman, micro-NMR and ESR techniques, among others. The experimental results are used to develop a model that describes the fs-laser response in terms of relevant glass structural parameters and ultimately design new glass compositions. This project is a collaboration between groups with expertise in optical materials and laser physics (UC-Davis) and glass chemistry (Missouri S&T) and provides training for graduate students in state-of-the-art materials science and optical techniques, research opportunities for undergraduates and outreach activities at the pre-college level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ultrafast lasers with pulses shorter than a trillionth of a second can be used to create micron-sized structures inside a piece of glass. This fabrication method provides a platform for the fabrication of photonic devices and circuits with applications in optical communications, bio-imaging and -sensing and nanotechnology. In order to exploit the full potential of this ultrafast laser ?writing? technique it is important to design materials that are optimized both in terms of device properties and  laser processing behavior. Towards this goal this project aimed to develop such materials as well as a detailed understanding of how the laser changes the materials structure on a microscopic scale. The research was a collaboration between UC Davis and Missouri S&T and provided training for graduate, undergraduate and pre-college  students in state-of-the-art materials science and optical techniques, research opportunities for undergraduates and outreach activities at the pre-college level. This project has resulted in 15 peer-reviewed publications and >25 invited and contributed conference presentations.

TECHNICAL DETAILS:

Femtosecond (fs)-laser writing of optical waveguides inside glass substrates ideally requires permanent modification of the glass structure resulting in a positive refractive index change as is, for example, the case for fused silica. Phosphate glasses, which are of interest as host materials for active devices since they allow incorporation of high concentrations of rare earth ions, typically produce negative refractive index changes in the laser-exposed regions. Before the start of this project we had found that good quality waveguides could be fabricated in zinc polyphosphate glass compositions with a [O]/[P] ratio close to 3.25. These glasses have networks that consist of small phosphate anions with interlinked PO4 and ZnO4 tetrahedra and are in that sense structurally similar to fused silica. This strongly suggests that it is the network structure of the glass that determines whether a positive index change can be induced. In this project we proposed to test the hypothesis that a specifically-designed glass structure determines the response to fs-laser exposure. In so doing, we aimed to develop a detailed understanding of how the laser-induced structural changes depend on initial glass structure and composition and to determine if the exposure to the extreme conditions of the fs-laser pulses creates structures that are otherwise not possible by conventional melt quenching techniques.

To carry out our experiments we built a combined femtosecond laser processing / confocal microscope setup to perform laser processing of the samples as well as spectroscopic characterization without having to remove the sample. The fs-laser system that we used in our experiments is a commercially available laser from Spectra-Physics which can deliver up to ~0.5 mJ of 130 fs-laser pulses at 800 nm with a repetition rate of 1 kHz. In a later stage of the project the laser system was extended with an optical parametric amplifier so that the output laser wavelength could be varied from 1100 nm to 1500 nm. 

With this experimental system we investigated femtosecond laser-matter interactions in ternary zinc phosphate glasses. We tested ten zinc aluminium phosphate glasses with increasing [O]/[P] ratios. We were able to produce optical waveguides inside zinc aluminium phosphate glasses with an [O]/[P] ratio equal to 3.25, independent of the aluminium content. The observed refractive index change was ~3x10-4. Using confocal Raman spectroscopy we correlated the  laser-induced damage to a depolymerization of the glass network, where Q2 species decrease while Q1 and Q0 species increase. We also used fs laser inscription to fabricate waveguide Bragg gratings (WBG) inside a ternary zinc magnesium phosphate glass.

We also studied of the influence of femtosecond laser wavelength on waveguide fabrication, starting with fused silica glass as a model system. The fabrication of waveguides and tracks of damage was demonstrated using laser wavelengths from UV to NIR. The size of the laser inscribed lines, the material modification thresholds and structural changes show a strong dependence on laser wavelength. Shorter wavelengths lead to smaller laser-written spatial features, lower thresholds, and a narrower laser energy range for fabricating waveguides. Using numerical simulations that consider the laser-excited electron plasma dynamics along with Gaussian beam optics we calculated the size of the laser-affected volume. The experimentally and numerically determined diameters of the laser-affected zone have been compared, showing excellent agreement.

To further unravel the physical mechanisms at play during fs-laser modification, we investigated the transient optical properties as well as the plasma emission spectroscopy of the laser-irradiated volume inside fused silica.  We studied the temporally and spectrally resolved transmission of a fs-laser-induced electron plasma inside fused silica using using a broadband supercontinuum probe. We modeled the interaction of the probe beam with the plasma by combining a Drude?Sommerfeld model with Gaussian optics. We find good agreement between experiments and simulations. Plasmas with densities on the order of 1021 cm-3 are generated when using a laser processing energy that results in good-quality optical waveguides.
